  • REGISTRY

Greg and I live happily in Dallas, Texas with our overly needy black lab mystery, Tux. We met sometime in late 2009 while we both worked at Team Detroit. We started as friends and would hang out all the time. After Greg decided I wasn’t that annoying, didn’t really talk too loud, or laugh all that loud; and after I realized how cute he was, it became something more. In March 2011 Greg was offered an amazing opportunity at 3008, a post house in Dallas, Texas. The following July, with daddy’s approval, I moved as well. Greg is still with 3008 doing sound design and mixing for commercials. I had a couple jobs and landed and amazing position with Color Box Letterpress, doing letterpress invitations for weddings, galas and whatever else comes across my desk. We’re excited to see everyone and be with our family and friends for such a joyous occasion!

PROPOSAL

We had planned a trip to Fredericksburg, a cute little town full of wineries outside of Austin, Texas. The funny thing is this trip was my idea, but ended up being very convenient for Greg’s plan; one, which I was very much unaware of. When we arrived in Fredericksburg the obvious first stop would be to pick up the keys for our bed and breakfast, I couldn’t wait to go check it out. But Greg insisted that we should go see Enchanted Rock park, a place we had planned to hike in the morning. Agreeable and oblivious, we headed for the park. Preparing for a fun hike I changed into a tank top, sports bra and hiking boots giving Greg a chance to grab the ring from his bag in the trunk.

Let me set the scene, beautiful rocky park and the sun is about to set. Still completely unaware of what’s going on, I want to get up to the top before the sun sets so we’re really trekking. We get to the top, the sky is beautiful and pink. The moon is starting to come out. I’m taking the in the view and turn around to Greg, who is down on one knee. I have no idea what he said, I’m sure something very sweet, but all of the sudden I was down on my knees too. He makes sure everyone knows I cried (it was only a little) and obviously accepted.

We had an amazing weekend and sampled a bunch of wine.

CEREMONY AND RECEPTION

The ceremony and reception will be held at the Inn on Ferry Street. It’s an outdoor event but will be on cobblestone and pavement, so no need to worry about your heels sinking into grass. The average temperature for July in Detroit is a low of 65 and high of 85.

The Inn on Ferry Street is located in midtown Detroit, just steps from the state’s finest museums, hotels and dining. Consisting of four restored Victorian homes, and two carriage houses the Inn abounds in sophisticated luxury. The Inn evokes a strong sense of history that provides the perfect atmosphere for weddings, receptions and other social events.

East Ferry Street was originally developed in the late 1800s into an upper-class neighborhood. Eventually the homes collectively came under ownership by the Detroit Institute of Arts in the 1970s and remained so until the renovation of the buildings began in February 2000 for The Inn On Ferry Street. They continue to be a hidden gem in the city.

PLAN YOUR TRIP

I’ve always loved Detroit, it’s full of history and grit and charm that not everyone sees. My dad used to run the restaurant and catering at the DIA, where my brothers and I spent many an afternoon wandering the galleries. My gramma would take us to the Fox and Cobo for various events to ensure we had culture in our lives. When I started planning my wedding I knew it would be in Michigan and I wanted it to be a location that would be fun for everyone coming from out of town. I hope I managed that, and you can take a glance at some of our favorite spots in Detroit proper and the suburbs north of the city.

There are so many amazing restaurants, too many to visit in a weekend, so here are a select few. Corktown and Midtown have had a rebirth and they’re a bunch of new places I don’t even know about. Greg recently sent me this article, which I found funny and helpful… Click Me

ACCOMODATIONS

Here are a few suggestions for hotels nearby:

Westin Book Cadillac 1114 Washington Boulevard, Detroit, MI 48226 http://www.bookcadillacwestin.com/

The MGM Grand Detroit 1777 Third Street, Detroit, MI 48226 http://www.mgmgranddetroit.com/hotel/ Doubletree Fort Shelby 525 West Lafayette Boulevard, Detroit, MI 48226 http://doubletree3.hilton.com/en/hotels/michigan/doubletree-suites-by-hilton-hotel-detroit-downtown-fort-shelby-DTTLFDT/index.html

RESTAURANTS and BARS

Supino Pizzeria 2457 Russell Street, Detroit, MI 48207 in Eastern Market http://supinopizzeria.com/ Expect a wait, it’s a tiny place, but expect delicious giant thin crust pizza. Guy Fieri went once, so it must be cool right? And get one with speck on it, because its speck.

Green Dot Stables 2200 West Lafayette, Detroit, MI 48216 http://greendotstables.com/ Opened by my brother’s longtime friend and his wife, Green Dot has become a Detroit staple. With weekly specials and a menu full of gourmet sliders and sides, everything is $3. Again, a wait is generally expected but so is a belly full of amazing food. I generally go straight here from the airport for lunch or dinner.

Café d’Mongos Speakeasy 1439 Griswold Street, Detroit, MI 48226 A hole in the wall across the street from a gentlemens club, this speakeasy gets pretty full late night. The soul food menu and décor (obviously collected over many years) creates a cool atmosphere for taking in the live music that’s bound to be on.

Bucharest Grill 2040 Park Avenue, Detroit, MI 48226 inside the Park Bar They serve shawarma with fries inside. INSIDE. That’s serious.

Cliff Bell’s 2030 Park Avenue, Detroit, MI 48226 A jazz club almost as old as prohibition, opened in 1935 and done up in mahogany and brass. With a menu to delight and an art deco atmosphere that brings you right back to the 30s. The Croque Madam is a must order!

Anita’s Kitchen 22651 Woodward Avenue, Ferndale, MI 48220 http://anitaskitchenonline.com/ This Lebanese menu is a stop for the two of us every time we’re in town. The hummus is amazing and even better if you mix in the garlic sauce, just commit to smelling like it afterwards. The lamb shank is another serious commitment but I regret when I don’t order it. Greg’s go to is the lemon chicken, which sounds ordinary but they manage to take it up a notch. Oh, it’s also in the hood I used to live in before moving to Dallas.

Vinsetta Garage 27799 Woodward Avenue, Berkley, MI 48072 http://vinsettagarage.com/ An auto shop turned cool restaurant with a bathroom floor worth every cent. This place has mac n’ cheese that will literally change your life, and there are two foods I can’t lie about, mac n’ cheese and hummus. They have other things on the menu, but it’s parmesan crusted, so the mac is undeniable.

ATTRACTIONS

Leon and Lulu 96 West 14 Mile Road, Clawson, MI 48017 https://leonandlulu.com/ This eclectic home and accessories store resides a couple blocks from Greg’s first apartment. It used to be the Ambassador Roller Rink, so you’ll find the shop girls on roller skates serving popcorn and refreshments. If Greg let me, I would buy everything in the place!

The Detroit Institute of Arts 5200 Woodward Avenue, Detroit, MI 48203 http://www.dia.org/ The DIA is just steps from the Inn on Ferry street and its collection is among the top six in the United States, comprising a multicultural and multinational survey of human creativity from prehistory through the 21st century. It houses Diego Rivera’s, Detroit Industry, which he considers his most successful work, which is worth the admission alone. It has a special place in my heart and a secret spiral staircase that leads from the first floor to the Victorian gallery that we loved going up and down as kids.

Eastern Market http://www.detroiteasternmarket.com/ A gem of the city, full of retailers and restaurants, its an amazing overgrown farmers market. Visit Roma Café for homemade Italian served by an all male staff that may or may not be connected to the mob. If you want some great thai, visit Sala Thai in the restored firehouse. Visit the Detroit Mercantile Company for Michigan made gifts and clothes. Pop in R. Hirt Jr. Co for snacks and goodies or in Savvy Chic for candles and home items galore.

The Heidelberg Project 3600 Heidelberg Street, Detroit, MI 48207 https://heidelbergorg.presencehost.net/ An outdoor community art environment started by Tyree Guyton in 1986, originally designed as a creative response to the ongoing blight and decay in the neighborhood he grew up in. The elements of the canvases, many of which are the houses themselves, are made up of found objects, most of which were salvaged from the streets of the city.

The Henry Ford Museum and Greenfield Village 20900 Oakwood, Dearborn, MI 48124 www.thehenryford.org The Henry Ford is the ultimate place to explore what Americans past and present have imagined and invented. It’s impossible not to feel a sense of awe as your mind adjusts to a different sense of scale — more vast, more expansive and more diverse— by far— than anything you'll encounter in everyday life. The sweeping, single-floor space with its soaring 40-foot ceilings covers nine acres dedicated to showcasing the finest collection of its kind ever assembled. Entering Greenfield Village is like stepping into an 80-acre time machine. It takes you back to the sights, sounds and sensations of America’s past. There are 83 authentic, historic structures, from Noah Webster’s home, where he wrote the first American dictionary, to Thomas Edison’s Menlo Park laboratory, to the courthouse where Abraham Lincoln practiced law. You can ride in a genuine Model T or “pull” glass with world-class artisans. Greenfield Village is a celebration of people — people whose unbridled optimism came to define modern-day America. http://www.thrillist.com/entertainment/detroit/the-worst-decisions-you-can-make-in-detroit
